Award.AwardTitle: Ultrawide Bandgap Gallium Oxide: Fundamental Understanding From Materials Synthesis to Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical description: Gallium oxide is a promising material for high-voltage, high-temperature, and high-frequency components in radar and communication systems, wind turbines, and rail traction. Its band gap of ~4.9 electron volts and estimated high breakdown voltage significantly goes beyond currently developed materials, such as GaN and 4H-SiC, while still presenting semiconductor properties. This research focuses on the theoretical modeling of gallium oxide for predicting its fundamental material properties, and the experimental synthesis of this material by using high purity metallic gallium and oxygen as sources. The project aims to produce high quality gallium oxide and to advance the fundamental understanding of this emerging material. Theoretical studies of the fundamental properties of imperfections in the material provides guidance for experimental material growth and material characterization. The development of strategies for synthesis of this material and progress in understanding their properties contribute an important body of work to the research infrastructure. A successful execution of this research is expected to provide a knowledge foundation to power electronics industry with positive impacts on the US economy. This project trains two graduate students in the areas of advanced semiconductor materials synthesis, material characterization, first-principles modeling and device technologies. The research is integrated with educational activities and outreach to benefit the broader community.

Technical description: The key research goal is to identify and address the fundamental material challenges of synthesizing high quality ultra-wide-band-gap (UWBG) gallium oxide to advance the next generation high power electronics and short wavelength optoelectronics. The synthesis and fundamental understanding of gallium oxide is still very much in its infancy. The exploration of native defects such as vacancies, interstitials, antisites, and impurities or intentional dopants is expected to be complex because three different oxygen sites and two different gallium sites need to be considered. The research team investigates these problems by combining first-principles modeling with a proposed novel synthesis method for achieving high quality epitaxial gallium oxide films. Specifically, the research efforts include: (i) a low pressure chemical vapor deposition approach to grow gallium oxide; (ii) reduce defects and improve material quality by growing gallium oxide on off-axis substrates; (iii) calculations of the energy of formation and defect levels for point defects, candidate dopants and defect complexes and their experimental signatures, such as electron paramagnetic hyperfine and g-tensors and optical properties; (iv) investigate the crystal defects on electrical properties of gallium oxide. This project provides fundamental understanding of electronic structure, phonons, transport, defects and growth optimization. The theoretical studies will assist in identifying the chemical nature of specific defect levels and thereby will provide guidance for experimental material synthesis and material characterization. The results from this project will fill the knowledge gap in this field, and build a foundation for future applications of this material system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Gallium oxide is a promising material for high-voltage, high-temperature, and high-frequency components in radar and communication systems, wind turbines, and rail traction. It promises electronic device performance significantly beyond currently developed materials, such as GaN and 4H-SiC. The project aims to produce high-quality gallium oxide with low defect-concentration and to advance the fundamental understanding of this emerging material. The major research findings are:

(1) We have established the growth of semiconductor beta-gallium oxide (β-Ga2O3) films via low-pressure chemical vapor deposition (LPCVD), which represents a scalable low-cost growth technique. Gallium oxide LPCVD growth was demonstrated on various substrates, including (010), (001) native β-Ga2O3  and c-plane sapphire substrates. Effective n-type doping in LPCVD β-Ga2O3 using silicon was demonstrated. Our finding revealed that the use of off-axis c-sapphire significantly improves the β-Ga2O3 material quality grown on lattice-mismatched c-sapphire substrates.

(2) Using the knowledge-base established from LPCVD β-Ga2O3 film growths, a similar technique was used for indium oxide (In2O3) films on off-axis c-sapphire and yttria-stabilized zirconia substrates. LPCVD growth of high-quality In2O3 films with high mobilities and fast growth rates (up to 113 ?m/hour)  was demonstrated.

(3) The LPCVD β-Ga2O3 growth window was expanded to relatively high growth temperature regime ~1000 οC, which led to high electron mobilities (>150 cm2/Vs at room temperature) grown on Ga2O3 substrates, and record high electron mobilities (>120 cm2/Vs at room temperature) on off-axis c-sapphire substrates. Quantitative defect spectroscopies confirmed a low total trap concentration in LPCVD grown β-Ga2O3. In addition, we have demonstrated the feasibility to grow β-Ga2O3 on top of thermally conductive diamond substrates. 

(4) The LPCVD grown β-Ga2O3 materials were also distributed to other research teams to i) demonstrate β-Ga2O3 based Schottky barrier diodes; ii) characterize nanomechanical resonation and demonstrated as nanoelectromechanical oscillator for real-time middle ultraviolet light detection; and iii) probe the origins/mechanisms of defect states through optical characterization.

(5)  We focused on defect electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) related parameters, which provide exquisite detail on the defect spin distribution. Our calculations assisted in identifying the EPR centers related to Ga-vacancies. The tetrahedral Ga-vacancy pair - Ga interstitial complex, proposed earlier was found to explain the main EPR center. Another optically activated EPR center, previously associated with a self-trapped polaron was shown instead to correspond to an off-symmetry-plane octahedral Ga vacancy. The EPR parameters were also determined for Mg and Zn acceptors.

(6) We studied the band structure of (AlxGa1-x)2O3 in the monoclinic and rhombohedral structures establishing their range of stability as function of composition. This was shown to depend on whether equilibrium is reached in the Al distribution over octahedral and tetrahedral sites. The band gaps were determined using the accurate quasiparticle self-consistent (QS)GW method including  lattice polarization effects.

(7) We determined the QSGW band structures of wurtzite-like Li(Na)GaO2  and established their structural stability relative to other structures with octahedral coordination. These materials have even larger band gaps than β-Ga2O3  with a more symmetric crystal structure lattice-matched to GaN, which would allow good thermal contact with a high thermal conductivity material for heat removal from devices and can be n-type doped with Si and Ge. Among the native defects, Ga (Li) vacancies were found to have high (low) energies of formation. This finding was corroborated by comparison with EPR data.

Overall, we have demonstrated LPCVD growth technique of β-Ga2O3 thin films as a promising method to produce materials for device applications in high power electronics and deep ultraviolet optoelectronics, we have contributed to the defect identification and paved the way toward even wider band gap semiconductors for future work.

Broader Impact:

Theoretical studies of the properties of imperfections in the material provides guidance for experimental material growth and material characterization. The development of strategies for synthesis of this material and progress in understanding their properties have contributed an important body of work to the research infrastructure. This project positions US at the forefront of gallium oxide material synthesis and material science innovation. This project has provided knowledge foundation to power electronics industry with positive impacts on the US economy.

This project has partially supported 9 students (7 experimentalists, 2 theorists) to develop their PhD dissertation and Master thesis, as well as 1 postdoc in theory to develop defects calculations. This project has trained these graduate students in the areas of advanced semiconductor materials synthesis, material characterization, first-principles modeling and device technologies. The graduate students also had the opportunities to collaborate with many researchers with different expertise and disciplines from academia, national laboratories, and industry.  

Results from this project have yielded 1 book chapter, 27 journal publications, 10 conference presentations, 1 MS thesis and 3 PhD dissertations. These findings have been disseminated to the broad research community through journal publications and conference presentations, and invited seminars given by the PIs and the students.
